section.name: ESIGate (Website Assembling Toolkit)
section.p: ESIGate (formerly known as "Website Assembling Toolkit") is a toolkit developed to help developers to integrate existing web applications and aggregate them as a single website.

ul.li: ESI reverse proxy : speed up your website using standard or custom (enhanced) ESI syntax.
CMS integration : include dynamic content from any CMS or website in your application easily.
Remote templating : use a remote template instead of embedded files and be able to completely change design (not only CSS) on the fly.
All together : combine and assemble multiple applications into a single, fast, modular and standard-compliant one.
Can be used stand-alone with any application or embedded in Java applications (JSP, JSF, Wicket and API support))

section.name: Reverse proxy and ESI processor
section.p: ESIGate can be used as a reverse proxy. Proxied pages can parsed in order to process inclusion instructions that the applications insert.
ESIGate fully support Edge Side Include specification 1.0
ESI enables to retrieve fragments of contents and use pages as templates from an application to another. You can also retrieve fragments from xpath expressions and apply xslt transformations.

section.name: Taglib
section.p: ESIGate offers a taglib that can be used in any JSP-based java web application.

Basically, the taglib looks like Tiles tag library except that it enables you to include contents and use templates coming from other applications that may have been written using any technology and deployed on other servers.

section.name: Other uses
section.p: Any functionality used by the taglib or the reverse proxy can be used through a simple API.

section.name: How it works
section.p: HTML pages are fetched from the provider server using regular HTTP requests. Pages are then parsed to find specific delimiters used to define the blocks. The blocks are then aggregated and sent to the browser as a single HTML page.
